pullRequest.body:
Given C^n manifolds (modelled on non-empty spaces), we prove that
- Sum.inl and Sum.inr are C^n, as well as Sum.map_elim and Sum.swap
- Furthermore, if both codomain manifolds are non-empty, Sum.map_elim is C^n iff both components are

From my bordism theory project.

---

Open questions:
- should the new file be renamed to `Constructions`? I'll be happy to do this in or after this PR.
- I've gone ahead and tagged a few more lemmas simp. I'd appreciate another pair of eyes if this is sensible. The current choices fail the simpNF linter.

- [x] depends on #20659
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [4a3f782e36](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20664/commits/4a3f782e3614058a6347f32beff772b76e2afae8)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ChartedSpace.sum_of_nonempty`
`+ ContMDiff.inl`
`+ ContMDiff.inr`
`+ ContMDiff.sum_elim`
`+ ContMDiff.sum_map`
`+ ContMDiff.swap`
`+ contMDiffAt_of_subsingleton`
`+ contMDiffOn_of_subsingleton`
`+ contMDiffWithinAt_of_subsingleton`
`+ contMDiff_of_contMDiff_inl`
`+ contMDiff_of_contMDiff_inr`
`+ contMDiff_of_subsingleton`
`+ contMDiff_sum_map`
`+ extChartAt_inl_apply`
`+ extChartAt_inr_apply`
`+ extend_image_target_mem_nhds`
`+ isEmpty_of_chartedSpace`
`+ nonempty_of_chartedSpace`
`+ sum_chartAt_inl_apply`
`+ sum_chartAt_inr_apply`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
There linter errors are from the simpNF linter: i.e., one should really look at the tagging to determine which option is best.
I have reverted the simp changes for now, to make CI pass and this PR show up in the queue. I'd still welcome opinions on them.

Interesting question (and technically out of scope of this PR, but worth considering regardless). I can certainly define the instance this way; I'm not sure how to work with that. (It seemed painful at first, but I haven't yet concluded if that's because it is a bad decision, or I'm missing a trick.)

Taking a step back: I'm not sure if removing that assumption is necessary/useful in practice. A non-emptiness assumption on `M` or `M'` would be annoying (and make bordism theory impossible), which is why I removed that. About H... I (tentatively) claim that every manifold you'll meet will be modelled on a non-empty space `H`, so this is no real restriction. Do you know a useful example which is different?
(And thanks for the tiny nits, of course.)
I pushed a commit starting to use your definition, so you can also look at what breaks (once CI comes back).

It's certainly never useful in applications to allow `H` to be empty. It's more that having useless assumptions around is not nice, because it propagates to all the other statements that use it, so if one can remove it from the start it makes for a cleaner theory.
I've done the cleanup, and I think it looks nice. What do you think?

Would it be possible to drop the nonemptyness assumption in the definition of the charted space structure on the disjoint union? I started with
```lean
/-- The disjoint union of two charted spaces on `H` is a charted space over `H`. -/
def ChartedSpace.sum_of_nonempty [Nonempty H] : ChartedSpace H (M ⊕ M') where
  ... the current definition

variable (H) in
lemma isEmpty_of_chartedSpace [IsEmpty H] : IsEmpty M := by
  rcases isEmpty_or_nonempty M with hM | ⟨⟨x⟩⟩ 
  · exact hM
  · exact (IsEmpty.false (chartAt H x x)).elim

open scoped Classical in
instance ChartedSpace.sum : ChartedSpace H (M ⊕ M') :=
  if h : Nonempty H then ChartedSpace.sum_of_nonempty else by
  simp only [not_nonempty_iff] at h
  have : IsEmpty M := isEmpty_of_chartedSpace H
  have : IsEmpty M' := isEmpty_of_chartedSpace H
  exact empty H (M ⊕ M')
```
I guess this would be a pain to work with in the first few API lemmas, but this should be fine after these. What do you think?

Would it be possible to drop the nonemptyness assumption in the definition of the charted space structure on the disjoint union? I started with
```lean
/-- The disjoint union of two charted spaces on `H` is a charted space over `H`. -/
def ChartedSpace.sum_of_nonempty [Nonempty H] : ChartedSpace H (M ⊕ M') where
  ... the current definition

variable (H) in
lemma isEmpty_of_chartedSpace [IsEmpty H] : IsEmpty M := by
  rcases isEmpty_or_nonempty M with hM | ⟨⟨x⟩⟩ 
  · exact hM
  · exact (IsEmpty.false (chartAt H x x)).elim

open scoped Classical in
instance ChartedSpace.sum : ChartedSpace H (M ⊕ M') :=
  if h : Nonempty H then ChartedSpace.sum_of_nonempty else by
  simp only [not_nonempty_iff] at h
  have : IsEmpty M := isEmpty_of_chartedSpace H
  have : IsEmpty M' := isEmpty_of_chartedSpace H
  exact empty H (M ⊕ M')
```
I guess this would be a pain to work with in the first few API lemmas, but this should be fine after these. What do you think?
Inlining this `set` makes the following have leave unsolved goals. I'm not fully sure why.
If there's a way to combine these proofs, I'm all ears.
The continuous analogue is called `continuous_sum_dom` and proves both the inl and inr statement. I'm not convinced that's better here.
I'd appreciate another opinion whether marking these lemmas simp is fine. I'm going purely by analogy: most `PartialHomeomorph.something_apply` lemmas are simp.

```suggestion
    (chartAt H (.inl x : M ⊕ M')) (Sum.inl x) = (chartAt H x) x := by
```

```suggestion
    (chartAt H (.inr x : M ⊕ M')) (Sum.inr x) = (chartAt H x) x := by
```

```suggestion
    (extChartAt I (.inl x : M ⊕ M')) (Sum.inl x) = (extChartAt I x) x := by
```

```suggestion
    (extChartAt I (.inr x : M ⊕ M')) (Sum.inr x) = (extChartAt I x) x := by
```

pullRequest.title: feat: Sum.inl and friends between smooth manifolds are smooth
